reviewText: When you think of Television mini series, you may think of such great television production in the 70's and 80s (its GOLDEN era) such like Backstairs at the White House, Upstairs Downstairs, The Bourne Identity (yes long before Matt Damon movie-with Richard Chamberlain and Jackie Smith), Roots (and the mini series sequel Roots the Next Generation), North and South (books 1-3), Noble House (with future James Bond Pierce Bronsnan), Shogun (with Richard Chamberlain), Jesus of Narazeth , Rich Man Poor Man (with newcomer Nick Nolte), Holocaust (with Meryl Streep and James Woods)or even The Thorn Birds (again with Chamberlain). These were some of the best TV had to offer. However, in April 1974 , the first NOVEL FOR TELEVISION (done on ABC TV) was presented. Over two nights.... Leon Uris QB V!!.The story of Abraham Cady (Ben Gazzara) learns of his Jewish heritage from his father (Dr No's Joseph Wiseman)-- that most of his family had been exterminated in the gas chambers at the Jadwiga concentration camp. After becoming penetrated in Jewish faith after his father's death, Cady decides to move to Israel and write a book called The Holocaust. In this book, Cady accuses a surgeon, Dr. Adam Kelno (played with Relish by Anthony Hopkins), as being one of the doctors at the Jadwiga camp that did experiments on other human beings and was a war criminal. Dr. Kelno finds out about the book and decides to sue Cady in court to prove that Cady is a liar. This is based of the real life case where Leon Uris was a defendant in a law suit growing from his novel Exodus, where someone sued Uris saying he were defamedTold in two parts, Kelno's story on the first night and the second night is Cady.story . This production lead the way for many future mini series. The production was filmed in Hollywood, England, Belguim and Israel and it shows in the production detailed filming.Lets talk supporting cast of this piece Leslie Caron, Milo O'Shea, Sir John Gielgud, Juliet Mills, Lee Remick, Joseph Wiseman, Sir Anthony Quayle, Jack Hawkins, and Kris Tabori-all holding their own with the talented leads Gazzara and Hopkins . This productionThis production is over 30 years old and it doesn't date itself. There are very strong message in this film even for today standards, the Holocaust usually is .. Parents should be advised it is VERY powerful. I suggest this for a teen and not a young child.So should you get this? Why aren't you ordering it now?Bennet Pomerantz AUDIOWORLD

reviewText: If you like courtroom dramas, you will love this.  In addition to a large, star-studded cast including American and British actors and actresses, the performances are uniformly marvelous, the script is taut and of full of meaning, without being one-sided.I was particularly impressed by the performance of a young Anthony Hopkins. A tortured soul, you feel alternately repulsed and sorry for him, because in his situation you might very well have done the same thing.  It is one of the most moving performances I have ever seen on film.This is a film to be relished over and over.  It is profound.

reviewText: Here's the backstory: Leon Uris was accused of defaming a doctor in his book Exodus. He was sued in court (Queen's Bench VII) for liable. After a long and extremely expensive trial, he was found guilty & fined a farthing. (A farthing was at the time a quarter of a penny & the smallest denomination of currency in England!)So, to recoup the expenses of the trial, Leon Uris wrote a fictional rendition of the story around the doctor & the trial. He did a great job & this is the movie version.PS. As a special treat, check out the jury. There's a hint of Monty Python hidden there.
summary: A bit dated, but still very good!

reviewText: Movie versions of great books typically fall short of expectations, simply because there is no room in two hours to convey the whole message. In this case, however, the version lasts more than 5 hours, so there was time to adapt this wonderful story faithfully. This is done very well and with good attention to detail. Bear in mind, though, that because it was originally a mini series (and therefore meant to be watched in chapters over the course of several nights), the editing is done in "chapters", and it does not play like a normal movie. It really doesn't matter, because we get an opportunity to take breaks along the way without interrupting the flow. And breaks you need, because of the 5+-hour length. All in all, this is a faithful adaptation, and an excellent video.
summary: Great adaptation of a great book

reviewText: Anthony Hopkins gives a stellar performance in his role as a polish doctor accused of war crimes by an American author, Ben Gazzara. One of the best post war dramas ever produced for T.V. Most court room dramas tend to be long, drawn out and at some point become  dreary and boring. QBVII somehow avoids these pitfalls with a gripping story line and better than average performances by the supporting cast including Lee Remick and Leslie Caron.

reviewText: QB VII is a highly acclaimed TV mini-series that first aired in 1974 (it won 6 Emmy Awards).  It is approximately 6 hours long and divided into 4 parts of roughly equal length.  (The book by the same name is authored by Leon Uris).  The two central characters are Dr. Adam Kelno and Jewish Author Abraham Cady.  Cady writes a best-seller on the Holocaust which implicates Dr. Kelno of collaborating with the Nazis performing medical experiments on Jews in a Polish concentration camp.  Dr. Kelno sues for defamation and the court trial that results gives the book it's unusual name:  QB VII refers to the courtroom where the trial is held, Queen's Bench, Room 7.The movie is very true to the book, in fact, having read this book, I felt like I was visually "reading" the book while watching the movie.  While the book is more detailed, the movie is surprisingly good and captures the original intent and drama of the book.The all-star cast is superb, but Anthony Hopkins' performance as Dr. Kelno, is truly extraordinary.Suitable for adults and older teens.kone

reviewText: I first watched this mini series back in the 70's and enjoyed it.When it became available on DVD I knew it would be a welcome addition to my collection.A stellar cast many of whom are no longer with us (the beautiful Lee Remick, Jack Hawkins just to name two), bring this story of the Holocaust and its survivors to life seen through the eyes of the two protagonists in a libel trial.Both Ben Gazzara and Anthony Hopkins are excellent in their roles of the brash American novelist/war hero (is he a playboy or serious novelist?) and the tortured doctor/Knight of the Realm (is he a victim of the Nazi's or a collaborator?)The look of the DVD may seem dated to modern eyes as it was a made for television drama, but the scenes are well constructed and the story moves at a decent enough pace...Disc 1 explores the lives of both men and their families from shortly before the end of WWII until they finally meet on the steps of the Royal Courts of Justice in London.Disc 2. Concentrates on the court case itself showing the torment of the Anthony Hopkins character when facing the Jewish survivors. Was he the caring doctor he claims to be or someone involved in horrendous experiments?What will the jury decide?Will they find in favour of a renowned doctor who has been Knighted by the Queen?A holocaust survivor who has spent his life since the war saving lives. From the deserts of Kuwait, to the back streets of London he has chosen to work amongst the impoverished and needy.Can he really be the man named by an American novelist as a war criminal? Someone who sterilised men, women and children in an attempt to eradicate the Jewish race?

reviewText: I've watched this movie years ago and read the book. It was so touching, it's fiction movie but some of the events did happen! I was in Germany watching a documentary at the one of the concentration camps, I was crying my eyes out, watching the horror that felt on the Jewish people, and when Ben Gazzara was in the court room watching the documentary and he was wiping his tears, I could feel his pain! I was trying to find this movie for eternity, so glad I found it ! Mind you, I'm not Jewish and no politics, this movie was so touching it stays with me after all these years.

reviewText: Ben Gazzara plays a rather cynical Jewish author who is inspired to write about an ex concentration camp doctor played by Hopkins. The book tells of the inhumane things that were done to the inmates of the camp. The doctor is outraged and sues the author for defamation. The trial takes up most of the second half of the film. Queen's Bench Seven is the name of the court room. Films are shown about the Holocaust and they are as horrific today as they ever were. The trial has the only kind of ending that it could have and that means that there really are no winners in a story like this one. It's great drama even if a bit harrowing at times and the cast turns in some great performances. This was actually the first TV mini-series and was shown in at least two parts when it first came out. Written by Leon Uris and based on a similar court case that he was involved in. Well worth your time even though it's a bit slow to start with.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "QB VII" is a great read and almost as good a view!  Despite some slow moments, it is a captivating movie crossing the lives of two men.  Each has seemingly redeemed himself for sins of the past.  One does it successfully, yet is ultimately punished.  The other is unsuccessful and continues to  live with his demons until he has falsely convinced himself that his sins are in the past and forgotten.  But his sins are beyond redemption in this world as he discovers while his life dissolves in pain.  Performances by Ben Gazzara and Anthony Hopkins are brilliant.  The rest of the cast is simply great.

reviewText: This is a fascinating, first rate, astoundingly well acted TV mini-series bringing together two powerful characters -- Ben Gazzara as the Nazi hunter on a mission, and the mesmerizing Anthony Hopkins as the decorated doctor accused of being a Dr. Mengele-type experimenter on human beings in concentration camps during World War II.  It is hard to overstate how brilliantly well acted this film is.  The story is riveting and hard to step away from even for a moment.  If this were a book, it would be a page-turner.Gazzara has never been better or classier and this is one of Anthony Hopkins' best performances ever.  This award-winning movie compares favorably with any other drama on a similar subject, including Marathon Man, Judgment at Nuremberg -- what have you.  The movie is bold, disturbing, engrossing -- and pulls no punches regarding the nature of the experiments run in the camps. Not for the squeamish.I can't recommend this highly enough -- it was riveting television on first run, worthy of being a feature film, but it is richer for being a long-form TV mini-series.  Very serious subject matter, and very moving at times -- the wives of the two men are well played, agonizing over their husbands' struggle in court, with Hopkins' wife standing by her husband to the end, and Lee Remick as Gazzara's wife is great as well.  The climax is stunning.  Treat yourself to a wonderful piece of television and use it to educate a new generation of young people as well!
summary: Powerful!! Hopkins as doctor accused of being Nazi Dr. Death

reviewText: If you want a truly accurate portrayal of the times and attitudes, of the way WWII affected people and the decades to follow, you could scarcely do better. Having scanned down to my review you surely have encountered already much about the historical importance of addressing the holocaust on national television, and of the moving performances. That is true of course. But forty years later, there isn't anything of historical nature here I have not by now seen already enough times. What I like is the honest representation of people and situations.We see here imperfect people in an imperfect world. Good people forced into a harsh existence and the possible failure of their human qualities. Their struggle to maintain or regain this humanity and how it affects those around them.This is a very accurate portrayal of how people thought and how people acted and how the events of the war affected their complete and entire lives. To which, if there is anything else you want to understand about the fifties or especially the sixties whether it be civil rights or Vietnam, you can learn much by watching this mini-series.If I have one criticism it would be that it moves just a little slow. But it is very well cast with excellent performances and we can forgive a fault or two. I don't regret the time I spent and I expect you will not either.

reviewText: This movie was truly like reading a well written book.  Its storyline and characters were so unpredictable and full of surprises. Every character, so well developed, contributed additional meaning to the story.The story itself follows the lives of two separate yet in ways similar men. Beginning at the end of WWII, the story cleverly brings these two men together some 25 years later, pitting them against one another in a trial of epic proportions.The movie just got better and better as it climaxed toward a most rewarding ending.  I haven't seen many movies like this that make you feel like you're reading a novel.  Again, very impressed with how everything developed and played out in the end.  I only wish I had watched it with others instead of alone.  Then again, maybe it was meant to be absorbed alone, like a good book. Simply Outstanding!!!5+ stars
